race.name: Gravel Burn
race.tagline: South African highveld classic‚Äî100km of red dirt roads, 2,500m elevation, stunning Mpumalanga scenery.

terrain.primary: South African highveld‚Äîrolling red dirt gravel
terrain.surface: 85% gravel, 15% dirt roads. South African highveld‚Äîrolling terrain, red dirt roads. 2,500 m over 100 km. Scenic Mpumalanga. Technical rating: 3/5.

biased_opinion.summary: Gravel Burn is South African highveld classic‚Äî100 km, 2,500 m elevation. Founded ~2018. 85% gravel, 15% dirt. Red dirt roads (iconic South African). Rolling highveld terrain. 500-700 riders. Mpumalanga scenic region. October spring conditions (15-30¬∞C). Affordable entry (R1,500-R2,000 / $80-$110). If you want African gravel adventure with stunning scenery, this is it. If you want local/domestic race, skip it. International destination race.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: Gravel Burn is South African red dirt adventure. 100 km, 2,500 m, stunning highveld scenery. If you want African gravel destination race with affordable entry, this is it. If you want local/domestic, skip it. International travel required but worth it for scenery and experience.

logistics.travel_summary: Fly to Johannesburg (JNB). Rental car needed (250 km, 3-hour drive to Mpumalanga). Book lodging early. Day-before packet pickup. Race October.
logistics.food_options: Aid stations on course. Post-race party.
logistics.camping: campsite in Merino Farm at 1,300m above sea level

course_description.character: 100 km, 2,500 m. 85% gravel, 15% dirt. South African highveld‚Äîrolling red dirt roads. Technical rating: 3/5.

suffering_zones.name: Throughout: Highveld Rolling Terrain
suffering_zones.description: Rolling South African highveld. 2,500 m cumulative. Red dirt roads.
suffering_zones.survival_strategy: Pace conservatively. Low gears. Hydrate (heat risk up to 30¬∞C).

suffering_zones.name: Throughout: Heat Management
suffering_zones.description: October spring = 15-30¬∞C. Heat risk. Sun exposure.
suffering_zones.survival_strategy: 3+ bottles. Hydrate at every aid. Sun protection. Manage heat.

course_description.signature_challenge: South African highveld rolling terrain + October heat. Red dirt roads.

history.origin_story: Gravel Burn founded ~2018. South African highveld gravel. 100 km, 500-700 riders. Mpumalanga. Red dirt roads. Growing international field.
history.reputation: South African gravel classic. Highveld red dirt. International destination.

logistics.explanation: International travel to Gqeberha plus seven-day stage race logistics across remote Karoo regions. The inaugural 2025 edition faced 'extreme weather conditions' that forced stage neutralization, showing how African storms can disrupt even well-organized events. While the full-service Burn Camps handle tent setup and meals, you're still managing customs, gear transport, and multi-timezone coordination to reach the Great Karoo. As Evening Activities puts it: "Riders would gather around campfires, sharing stories of the day's challenges while mechanics worked on their bikes and support staff handled the washing."

length.explanation: Seven stages of 90-140km each totaling 800km pushes most riders past their comfort zone without crossing into masochism. Race organizers note that 'completing the race requires endurance, experience, and preparation ‚Äì qualities that are within reach of a moderately fit cyclist' with 12+ hours weekly training over six months. The cumulative fatigue matters more than individual stage distances. Similar distance to Crusher in the Tushar.

technicality.explanation: Described as 'relatively smooth, non-technical gravel roads' but terrain varies from 'wide, open Champagne Gravel to remote and narrow paths.' The route demands bike handling skills across coastal forests, Karoo semi-desert plains, and African bushveld. Andri Frischknecht's crash during a neutralized section shows that even non-technical terrain poses handling challenges in exposed conditions. Similar technical demands to Gravel Worlds. As Stage 3 puts it: "A mix of technical climbing, descending, and fast gravel"

elevation.explanation: 11,000m of climbing over 800km creates serious vertical density across South Africa's most dramatic landscapes. The route traverses 'rugged passes and breathtaking vistas' from Knysna's rolling coastal hills through the Great Karoo's expansive plains to Shamwari's African bushveld terrain. Seven days of accumulated climbing through these geological transitions will break plenty of riders by the final stages. More climbing than SBT GRVL at the same score. As Stage 3 puts it: "A mix of technical climbing, descending, and fast gravel"

climate.explanation: The inaugural 2025 race experienced 'extreme weather conditions' and significant storms that forced stage neutralization. October brings temperature swings from 95¬∞F daytime highs in the Great Karoo to sharp drops after sunset. Lateral wind gusts proved dangerous enough to cause serious crashes even during neutralized racing, highlighting the climate challenges of this arid semi-desert crossing. More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego. As Night before Stage 6 puts it: "A storm came in during the evening with strong, gale-force winds blowing down the nearby bergs into our campsite in Merino Farm at 1,300m above sea level."

altitude.explanation: Starting near sea level in Knysna and traversing Eastern Cape highlands means most elevation comes from climbing rather than sustained altitude stress. The route through Great Karoo and African bushveld likely stays below serious oxygen debt thresholds for most riders. Temperature and terrain pose greater physiological challenges than altitude in these South African highlands. Modest altitude compared to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

adventure.explanation: Riding through Big Five territory in fossil-rich semi-desert where 'the hardiest creatures thrive' maxes the adventure meter. You're literally crossing geological and ecological zones most humans never experience, let alone on a bike. The inaugural status means you're writing the first chapter of this race's story in some of Africa's most remote terrain.

prestige.explanation: The $150,000 prize purse makes this 'the largest in gravel racing history' and attracts elite fields including three-time Cape Epic winner Matt Beers and Paris-Roubaix champion Alison Jackson. Founded by Cape Epic creator Kevin Vermaak with Nedbank title sponsorship, the race launched with what Beers called 'a major milestone that will undoubtedly attract global attention, setting a new standard for gravel racing.'

race_quality.explanation: Full-service Burn Camps with two-night stays show they're not messing around with logistics and rider care. The routing from Knysna forests through the Great Karoo to Shamwari Game Reserve is masterfully planned ‚Äì each stage builds the narrative. Stage breakdowns like the 7km Tarka Botha climb followed by steep descents prove they understand how to design suffering with purpose. As Alistair Brownlee puts it: "I'm not in it for the medals and wins. I'm in it for the enjoyment. But, of course, I'm still going to go as hard as I can."

experience.explanation: The Burn Camps create 'camaraderie, storytelling, and shared adventure' with communal campfires and local cultural integration including live music and regional cuisine. Alison Jackson captured the appeal: 'I can't wait to make some new friends in the Burn Camps next to the fireside in the evenings.' Racing through three distinct ecosystems while living among Olympic champions creates an expedition-level experience.

community.explanation: When Andri Frischknecht crashed seriously, he thanked 'all other riders for their fairness and for stopping and taking care of me,' showing the mutual support culture. The Burn Camps foster connection through two-night stays with spacious tented accommodations where 'the prevailing atmosphere is one of camaraderie, storytelling, and shared adventure.' Pro-am integration lets riders 'live among Olympic and world champions.'

field_depth.explanation: Elite field includes Cape Epic winners Matt Beers and Annika Langvad, Paris-Roubaix champion Alison Jackson, and multiple world champions. The inaugural edition drew serious international talent with the $150,000 prize purse, but age-group depth remains to be proven. More than 20% of registered riders were women, showing strong gender representation for a new event seeking to establish competitive credibility. Similar competitive depth to Rule of Three.

value.explanation: Seven days, 800km, full-service Burn Camps, wildlife encounters, and airport transport options ‚Äì this is expedition-level experience for stage race entry fees. Most riders pay more for a long weekend at Leadville and get a fraction of the adventure. The all-inclusive model eliminates the usual multi-day race headaches of finding food and shelter.

expenses.explanation: International flight to Gqeberha plus seven days of racing and lodging adds up fast, even with race-organized transport options. The full-service model likely costs more upfront than bare-bones stage races, but eliminates surprise expenses. Budget for African adventure pricing, not domestic gravel race fees. Similar expense level to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

final_verdict.one_liner: A stage race trying to be Unbound with safari views, but the Karoo heat and seven-day commitment separate the curious from the committed.
final_verdict.should_you_race: If you've never done a multi-day gravel event, this isn't where you start‚Äîthe Karoo semi-desert doesn't forgive poor pacing or inadequate hydration systems. You need solid base fitness for 100km+ daily efforts and the mental fortitude for a week of accumulating fatigue. The full-service camps cushion the suffering, but those long drags to places like Conical Peak will expose fitness gaps quickly.
final_verdict.alternatives: Cape Epic offers similar South African adventure with better-established logistics and stronger international field. For stage race experience without the travel, consider Gravel Worlds' multi-day format or Trans Iowa if you want proper suffering without the safari marketing.

videos.title: Nedbank Gravel Burn Rider Experience | A 24-Hour Rider Experience Through the Great Karoo
videos.description:
Nedbank Gravel Burn isn‚Äôt just a race ‚Äî it‚Äôs a full 24-hour immersion into one of the world‚Äôs most spectacular landscapes and all it‚Äôs hidden treasures.

From sunrise coffee beside your tent to after dinner drinks under Great Karoo stars, this is gravel racing reimagined. Riders see rugged coastlines, semi-desert vistas and the iconic Big Five. Off the bike, it‚Äôs equally rich: Burn Camps feature comfortable tents, fire-lit Lapas and locally sourced fare.

Join the journey, where the ride is only part of the story.

üìÖ Dates: 26 Oct ‚Äì 1 Nov 2025
‚õ∞ Distance: 800km
üß≠ Climbing: 11,000m
üí∞ Prize Purse: $150,000 ‚Äì the biggest in gravel racing

videos.title: Men's Race Story | Nedbank Gravel Burn 2025
videos.description:
A complete look at the men‚Äôs race across seven days and eight hundred kilometres of South African gravel. This twenty six minute show follows the riders who shaped the inaugural edition and the men who pushed the pace through every stage.
The show brings together the key moments, the decisive moves and the full rider experience from Knysna to Shamwari. It captures the front of the race as it unfolded across forests, mountain passes and long Karoo gravel, along with the atmosphere of the race villages and the shared rhythm of the week.
This is the full story of how the men raced and experienced the first Nedbank Gravel Burn.
videos.transcript:
At the southern tip of Africa, beneath
skies that stretch to the horizon, a new
chapter in cycling story begins.
7 days and 786 kilometers, a journey of
dreams, dust, and discovery.
Set against the backdrop of vastly
contrasting landscapes, a gravel stage
race begins in lush coastal forests,
traverses the breathtaking semi- desert
of the great Karu over rugged mountain
passes into pristine, wild and iconic
African bushfeld. The treasures of
nature are revealed and it all
culminates where the big five roam free
at Shamoiri private game reserve. It's a
true proam field, bringing together some
of the world's best riders and intrepid
amateurs, each ready to be tested on a
scale the gravel cycling world has not
yet seen. At the end of the day's
endeavors, nightfalls. It's a full
immersion into the unique hospitality of
the guru. Firelight, flavors, and the
hidden secrets of the land. When the sun
sets on burn camp, something
extraordinary ignites. This is Nedbank
gravel burn.
The first edition of the Netbank gravel
Burn attracted some of cycling's global
elite ready to battle it out for a
record prize purse totaling 150,000 US.
The field included Olympic, world, and
national champions from every discipline
of the sport like Unbound 2025 runnerup
Simon Pelo.
>> On a gravel racing, you have no idea
what's coming. You know, the terrain can
change and the the flattest stage could
be like the hardest in the ends.
>> French national champion Ugo Dreu and
Olympic mountain bike champion Tom
Pitcock.
>> I expect a big big adventure from the
Gravel Burn, not just a race like any
other, especially because it happens the
first time, so no one really knows how
it's going to go. I'm really looking
forward to discover this adventure at
the Gravel. and Australian endurance
kingpin Lachlan Morton. South African
star Matt Beers arrived at the start
fresh from a successful season of racing
in the United States. I think the
Nedbang gravel bone is going to just be
unknown, rugged, gnarly,
but also a very cool experience.
>> They came from all parts of the world to
experience this full service gravel
state race in the most remote regions of
the Eastern Cape in South Africa. Rivals
on the bike by day. Each night they
recover and regail stories together,
forging bonds. Something rarely seen in
any professional sport.
From the coastal town of Nisner through
Forest and Prince Alfred's Pass, topping
out at over 1,000 m, stage 1 is 84 km
with 2,50 m of climbing, making it a
truly testing introduction to the week.
The official start at the Murings.
Wet conditions. This is a significant
moment in the fledgling discipline of
gravel racing.
Excitement levels are high as the pro
men's pelaton prepared for the first of
seven challenging stages. South African
Marco Eubair, one of several national
champions in the field in the neutral
roll out through town before facing the
initial climb of the day.
The flag dropped as they hit the slopes
at the 3 km Simola Hill that would take
care of 250 m of the day's 250 m of
climbing
onto the gravel for the first time. It
was muddy and slippery as they pedal
through the forest.
Lucas Bal looking to Peter Steter for
assistance in the pacemaking. It was a
journey into the unknown, but the
European riders like Rammon Singleam had
come prepared for unseasonal garden
route weather.
Former Gilro Ditalia stage winner Chad
Hager from the United States on his
first trip to South Africa and perhaps
wondering where the sun was. The sight
of Matt Beers and the blue and red
specialized off-road kit on the front
send shivers through the group. The tall
South African was born and raised in the
region and knows these roads better than
anyone.
Despite the conditions, they flew down
the descents at high speed and through
the first and second putt style of the
day. Hot styles, the name given by the
event to the service stations along the
route.
The defining climb loomed 14 kilometers
up the Prince Alfred's pass.
Ugodu drove the pace with 19 riders in
his wake. Simon Pelo chased hard to
close a gap. The group thinned out over
the first 5 km. Among them a handful of
national champions.
Halfway up, a group of three got away.
Beers, Dresu, and Swiss XO star Enri
Fchnik on a special bike setup
customized for this stage race. Beers
and Dashu did the line share of work on
the front as Fnick did all he could to
stay in touch. On the descents, it was
each man for himself.
A left off the descent and into the Zond
farm orchards. He led the charge into
what was a twisty technical last
kilometer.
Prishnik ducked inside Dresu to take
second position. In the sprint, he could
not close the gap and get around the
powerful beers ahead of him. And the
South African rounded the final corner
to ride himself into gravel racing
history as the first man to win a stage
and wear the Asos Ember leader jersey at
the Nedbank gravel burn.
The racing was desperately close all the
way through the standings and 48 seconds
between Tristan Noki in fourth and Simon
Pelo in fifth.
Despite the weather, the riders were
given a warm welcome by the energetic
and enthusiastic Burn Camp crew.
The crisp chill of the great karu
greeted riders ahead of stage two. Dry
roads and champagne gravel was on the

videos.title: GRAVEL BURN: RACING THE LONGEST GRAVEL RACE IN THE WORLD
videos.description:
The Gravel Burn in 2025 is a first year gravel stage race to which I was invited by Assos of Switzerland. This is my story of what happened during the 7 days. Hope you enjoy!

videos.title: HIGHLIGHTS SHOW | NEDBANK GRAVEL BURN 2025 - STAGE 3
videos.description:
Graaff-Reinet  ‚û°Ô∏è  Blaauwater.

It was yet another day of fierce racing in the Karoo today as the riders made the fast and rugged move from Graaff-Reinet to Blaauwater. 

Lauren Stephens (Aegis Cycling Foundation) of the United States timed a final attack to perfection to claim the win after a day of tactical racing in the Pro Women‚Äôs race. 

Simon Pellaud (Tudor Pro Cycling) of Switzerland also finally achieved what he‚Äôd been threatening to do since race registration on Saturday with a well-timed counter-attack on the finish line. 

The Nedbank Gravel Burn is South Africa‚Äôs ultimate multi-stage gravel race, seven days of rugged routes, iconic climbs, and world-class competition. Explore the stages, results, and event info at https://gravel-burn.link

Stay tuned to our socials for daily highlights, results, and behind-the-scenes action:
YouTube: ‚Ä™@Gravel_Burn‚Ä¨

Facebook:   / facebook.com/gravelburn

quotes.text: It went below freezing last night because there is a frost and everything's frozen, including my tent. I woke up at like 3:00 in the morning with my feet frozen and I put like three pairs of socks on and then I thought I was going to die.

The brutal steep ascent was for many riders a nightmare of rocks, stones, and loose terrain, stunting momentum and forcing them off their bikes on occasion as they dug deep to reach the summit. The carnage was real and the pelaton was shattered.
I'm tired and congested from the dust. I think it will be a lot more crazy than yesterday. I got the big tires, the monster truck tires, 2.2 mountain bike tires.

key_challenges.name: Shellot climb
key_challenges.description: A brutal steep ascent described as a nightmare of rocks, stones, and loose terrain that stunts momentum and forces riders off their bikes. Called a pivotal race defining course that shatters the peloton.

key_challenges.name: Prince Alfred's Pass
key_challenges.description: A defining climb of 14 kilometers up Prince Alfred's Pass, topping out at over 1,000 meters elevation.

terrain_notes.text: First stage features muddy and slippery conditions through forest sections with wet gravel.
Stage one conditions were described as grim, wet, and cold enough to finish a whole pair of brake pads.
Stage 4 includes an 80 km tarmac section that riders celebrated as a relief from gravel.

gear_mentions.text: Van Risal CGR set up with 45 mm tubeless tires was used as a trusty race setup.

race_day_tips.text: Riders need to be prepared for extreme weather variations - freezing temperatures at night that can freeze tents and gear, requiring multiple pairs of socks.
Some riders chose to take easier days to recover after being pushed over their limit, accepting a position further back to manage the week-long effort.

additional_quotes.text: I woke up at like 3:00 in the morning with my feet frozen and I put like three pairs of socks on and then I thought I was going to die, but I made it. And I think I have all of my toes still.
On a gravel racing, you have no idea what's coming. You know, the terrain can change and the the flattest stage could be like the hardest in the ends.
At the end of the day's endeavors, nightfalls. It's a full immersion into the unique hospitality of the guru. Firelight, flavors, and the hidden secrets of the land.

rider_intel.search_text: Gravel Burn is a seven-stage, 786-800km gravel race across South Africa featuring extreme terrain variations and challenging conditions. Key obstacles include the brutal Shellot climb with rocks, stones and loose terrain that forces riders to dismount, and the 14km Prince Alfred's Pass climb reaching over 1,000m elevation. Stage one presents muddy, slippery forest sections in wet conditions cold enough to destroy brake pads. The race traverses from coastal forests through the Karu Desert to wildlife reserves, with stages including 80km tarmac sections. Riders face extreme weather from freezing nighttime temperatures that freeze tents and gear to desert heat. The event combines professional racing with a $150,000 prize purse and burn camps featuring communal dining and campfires. Terrain constantly changes making flat stages potentially the hardest, requiring strategic pacing across the week-long effort.
